Loop over 2007-2009 water-quality CSVs; read each file into a dataframe.
Within each year’s data frame, split rows by the value in 'Beach Type Description' to isolate Marine and Fresh beaches.
For each type, flag exceedances by selecting rows whose 'Violation' column (case-insensitive) equals 'yes'.
Compute yearly exceedance rate for each type:  (# rows with violation) / (# rows of that beach type); store these three yearly rates in separate Marine and Fresh lists.
Convert the two lists of rates to NumPy arrays so they align by year (length 3).
Define summer months Jun, Jul, Aug.

For Marine rainfall: read the monthly_precipitations_*.csv files for Boston and Chatham; keep Year + summer-month columns, keep only 2007–2009 rows, cast month columns to float, sum Jun+Jul+Aug per year to get a summer total, then average the two cities’ totals year-wise to obtain a (3-value) marine_rains array.
For Fresh rainfall: repeat the same procedure for Boston, Chatham, Amherst and Ashburnham, then average the four cities year-wise to obtain a (3-value) fresh_rains array.
Use numpy.corrcoef to calculate the Pearson correlation between the 3-year exceedance-rate vector and the 3-year rainfall vector for Marine beaches; repeat for Fresh beaches.
Print both correlation coefficients and compare them to determine which beach type shows the higher summer rainfall-exceedance correlation.
